paragraphs.text: Will Putin bite off more than he can chew?
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: During a radio interview this week, French President Francois Hollande said Russian President Vladimir Putin "doesn't want to annex eastern Ukraine - he told me that"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: He even suggested that western sanctions should be eased
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Hollande's naivety harks back to George W Bush's infamous comments about Putin in 2001
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: When asked by a reporter if he could trust Putin, he responded;"I looked the man in the eye
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: I found him to be very straightforward and trustworthy
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: I was able to get a sense of his soul."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: As a former KGB officer, Putin probably looked into Bush's eyes and saw a case number!
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In reality, Putin has done nothing to demonstrate that his commitment to Hollande is genuine
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Crimea is still under the control of Russia after its illegal annexation last year
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Moscow continues to occupy the Georgian breakaway provinces of Abkhazia and South Ossetia
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Russian weapons and equipment are still pouring into eastern Ukraine
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As recently as last November, NATO confirmed another build-up of Russian military equipment and troops inside Ukraine
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Russia's next moves
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: In light of Russia's recent behaviour, what can be expected in eastern Ukraine in 2015?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Predictions of this sort are almost impossible and are usually invariably wrong
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it is possible to develop various scenarios that could offer a glimpse into what Russia's plans might be
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Russia's ultimate goal is to keep Ukraine out of the transatlantic community - the EU and NATO
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Russia will also want to consolidate the gains made by separatist forces in eastern Ukraine
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: To this end, Russia will have short-term and long term goals
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The primary short-term goal for Russia in Ukraine will be to keep the conflict in eastern Ukraine "frozen"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: meaning that while the bullets might stop flying, there will be no real effort to bring a conclusive end to the conflict
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This equates to victory for Moscow and defeat for Kiev
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it leaves Ukraine not in control of all its territory
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Russia can also use the "frozen" status of separatist-controlled regions of Donetsk and Luhansk as bargaining chips in future talks with the West on other issues
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In terms of Russia's longer term goals in Ukraine for 2015 and beyond, there are a number of scenarios that can play out
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It is safe to assume that Moscow will help the separatists consolidate gains in Donetsk and Luhansk to create a political entity that becomes more like a viable state
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This will be no easy task and will require the capture of important communication and transit nodes, such as Donetsk airport, the city of Mariupol and its port, and the Luhansk power plant
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: These are still under Ukrainian government control but are all needed if the separatists want to achieve true autonomy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A more ambitious scenario might see Russia expanding separatist-controlled areas to include the entire eastern region of Ukraine consisting of the Donetsk and Luhansk oblasts and the eastern sections of Dnipropetrovsk and Kharkiv oblasts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This would require capturing Kharkiv
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which is Ukraine's second largest city
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: Kharkiv also holds a certain degree of symbolism for those in Moscow dreaming of the days of Soviet glory
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it was the first city in Ukraine to recognise the Bolshevik takeover in 1917
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The most aggressive scenario might see Moscow attempting to re-establish control of the historical Novorossiya region in modern-day southern Ukraine
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This would create a land bridge between Russia and Crimea
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: eventually linking up with the Russian-backed Transnistria, a breakaway region of Moldova
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This would be no easy undertaking and would require the capture of the heavily defended cities of Mariupol and Odessa, Ukraine's tenth-largest and third- largest cities, respectively
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Russia is desperate to establish a land bridge to Crimea
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: since
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the cost of providing goods and services by sea and air to the peninsula is becoming prohibitively expensive
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In fact
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Putin has ordered a bridge linking the Russian mainland with Crimea to be built by 2018
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: With an economy in recession, the collapse of the rouble, and the low price of oil, finding the $5.2bn required to build the bridge might not be possible
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Instead
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Russia could be forced into creating a land bridge to Crimea
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Out of all of Russia's previous leaders, Putin has more in common with Russia's imperial czars than he does with the Soviet premiers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Perhaps Putin has most in common with Emperor Nicolas I
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: who ruled Russia between 1825 and 1855
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Nicolas I's reign was marked by a stagnate economy, territorial expansions in the Caucasus, the crushing of political dissent, and a war in Crimea
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In the case of Nicolas I, his war in Crimea was disastrous and could have had serious implications for his rule if he had not died from pneumonia before the war ended
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Will Crimea prove the same for Putin today?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Only time will tell
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: One thing is for certain
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Russia's designs on eastern Ukraine are far from over, 2015 will prove to be a very interesting year
paragraphs.label: assumption
